review_title: Antiquated expectations of a work/life balance; be prepared to sacrifice.
job_title: Medical Editor/Scientific Writer in Baltimore, MD
pros: Working on the manuscripts is challenging, but in a good way. I found that doing substantive editing to make papers worthy of submission was a rewarding and interesting process. The contributing authors respected my notes and opinions and typically deferred to my expertise, which made me feel capable and valued. Although the attending surgeons may be difficult to pin down due to their busy schedules, they are agreeable people who let it be known that they appreciate your efforts.
cons: Direct management of this position has a punitive style that does not cultivate motivation, morale, or team-building. You will be expected to commute into the office every day. You will be expected to work more than 40 hours and have your effort and dedication questioned unless you you stay late. You will be expected not to take any days off of work from July 4th until the end of the summer course (typically in late August). You will also be expected to work evenings and weekends during much of that time in the summer.

pros: Hours Okay Benefits Secure hours

review_title: Poor departmental management; Awful HR department
pros:
- free parking
-most of the front line employees are good folks who work hard
cons:
- pay is low and intentionally kept at approx the 15 - 20th percentile of market value

 - in addition to low pay, schedule if often worse that it would be for the same position than at other institutions (i.e.  clinical pharmacists work every 3-4 weekends, where other institutions the same position would work every 4-8 weekends).  

- hospital will not pay for certifications (such as Board Certification), but they will sometimes require employees to gain these certifications or face demotion.

- Hiring internal candidates / transfers/ promotions: Will not follow their own policies or will find loopholes in order to not follow policy

- The health system management cares much more about themselves than the front-line employee.  Newsletters will have pictures of hospital administrators on every page, but rarely mention work of others.

- Administration will do employee surveys to identify issues, which are never addressed.  

- HR does not stand behind employees when management violates policies.

- Health-system will provided the cheapest health benefits possible (even self-funding their insurance and hiring an incompetent company to facilitate the health plan - which resulted in claims delayed by up to a year)

job_title: Patient Care Associate in Baltimore, MD
pros: Good experience if you do not have any.
cons: Very low pay, a lot fo work.

review_title: Sinai IS SOOOO CHEAP/ Cutback on everything except themselves!!!!!
pros: I like some of my co-workers.
cons: They want you to work like a dog with very little pay.  I see why so many Doctors and Nurses have left.  They don't want to pay you hardly nothing. They want you wear so many hats around here and don't want to pay you nothing.  I bet there pockets are being lined with there fat  bonuses. That's why they cut back on everything.  Food now is ridiculously expensive for employees.  They need to get rid of that new vendor. Such a rip off.  Sinai is a hostile environment especially in the E.R.  Poor management skills throughout.  I don't even know how they got their position. They must have known someone to help get them there.  There is lack of communication and poor mgmt.

job_title: Family Medicine Physician in Baltimore, MD
pros: Good no problem so far
cons: None I can currently think of

job_title: EMR Support Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: None that I can think of.
cons: Everything that I can think of.

pros:
Sinai:
Good salary.
Lead Tech is wonderful. She is a Tech herself. Will work open shifts if no one else available. Will back you! 
Manager has no CT experience.
24hr Subway for access to food on site.
On Site Parking... Free
Employees are generally friendly and helpful,, but sometimes you have to ask.
ER Docs, PAs, NPs are generally nice to work with.
Very diverse personnel.
Everyone is required to be respectful to EVERYONE. (coworkers, staff, Drs, NPs, PA.s, and patients)
Openings are due to people retiring, moving to another state, or patient volume.
cons:
Sinai:
You are highly recommended to park on campus.
Benefits are declining.
Can be extremely busy in ED. Extremely BUSY in ED.  
Can work short on a shift.
Radiologists can be very particular and nit-picky.
Patient population may not be respectful to you.

job_title: Desktop Support Tier II in Baltimore, MD
pros: Great place to work (outside of the IT department), friendly staff, decent cafeteria, great benfits and decent starting pay.
cons: The IT department is stuck in 1999. Most of the people that work there are seriously unqualified for their job positions and anyone who is competent leaves within a year. Many of these people have no clue about cyber security or enterprise level management. There is no direction, documentaiton, standards, or policies. One of the most technically incompetent IT departments I've ever experienced.

pros: They have a lot of employee assistance like workforce development (a life/career coach helps you to develop your career path, and works with you to implement it), workplace education (classes offered by Lifebridge that include learning how to use Microsoft programs, money management, bridge programs, and more), and also tuition assistance for part and full time employees. For the most part, there is teamwork, kindness, and support between everyone. The patients are happy, and they encouraged to stay active with a recreational department (something I haven't heard of anywhere else).
cons: Management don't always approve of employees taking classes, which leads them (the employee) to become stagnant. They are usually short staffed, and employees become burned out. High turn over rates.

pros: Nice employees, Lots of employee morale building activities, free parking
cons: Lack of communication, incompetent staff, poor annual raises, lack of advancement opportunities for minorities

pros: Dedicated co-workers, talented and approachable physician leadership, and mission-driven executive team with deep ties to the area.  This is an innovative health system that is committed to getting physicians and their teams the tools and the environment that they need to provide the best care for their patients, both inside and outside the four walls of the hospital.
cons: Very few "cons."  Large organization - like all health systems can be a bit democratic.

review_title: Growing organization looking to make an impact
pros: LifeBridge is truly focused on making a positive impact on the communities we serve. Our CEO is a brilliant and truly caring individual that inspires you when you interact with him. My leadership are a pleasure to work for. I have the opportunity to tackle challenging projects that are making a difference both in the organization and community
cons: I don't have anything to note.

pros: Loved the people- great place to work... wonderfull staff,  everyone was willing to pitch to help when needed. HR staff was always helpful
cons: None. I don't have any cons to talk about - my time at Sinai was wonderful and I would love to work there again.

review_title: Leading the Charge Toward Change and Growth

cons: Growth and change can sometimes feel unsettling, there have been many leadership changes in the organization and it can be difficult to reassure employees that changes are positive.

pros: This is an excellent organization that has a great reputation and strong role in the community. It fulfills a much needed service - health care for everyone who needs it.
cons: This organization is very focused on giving great care to its patients. There is a broad array of physicians from every discipline to care for patients from young to old.
